abstract: <jats:p>Common genetic variation frequently accounts for only a modest amount of interindividual variation in quantitative traits and complex disease susceptibility. Circulating adiponectin, an adipocytokine implicated in metabolic disease, is a model for assessing the contribution of genetic and clinical factors to quantitative trait variation. The adiponectin locus, <jats:styled-content style="fixed-case"><jats:italic>ADIPOQ</jats:italic></jats:styled-content>, is the primary source of genetically mediated variation in plasma adiponectin levels. This study sought to define the genetic architecture of <jats:styled-content style="fixed-case"><jats:italic>ADIPOQ</jats:italic></jats:styled-content> in the comprehensively phenotyped Hispanic (<jats:italic>n</jats:italic> = 1,151) and <jats:styled-content style="fixed-case">A</jats:styled-content>frican <jats:styled-content style="fixed-case">A</jats:styled-content>merican (<jats:italic>n</jats:italic> = 574) participants from the Insulin Resistance Atherosclerosis Family Study (<jats:styled-content style="fixed-case">IRASFS</jats:styled-content>). Through resequencing and bioinformatic analysis, rare/low frequency (<5% <jats:styled-content style="fixed-case">MAF</jats:styled-content>) and common variants (>5% <jats:styled-content style="fixed-case">MAF</jats:styled-content>) in <jats:styled-content style="fixed-case"><jats:italic>ADIPOQ</jats:italic></jats:styled-content> were identified. Genetic variants and clinical variables were assessed for association with adiponectin levels and contribution to adiponectin variance in the <jats:styled-content style="fixed-case">H</jats:styled-content>ispanic and <jats:styled-content style="fixed-case">A</jats:styled-content>frican American cohorts. Clinical traits accounted for the greatest proportion of variance (<jats:styled-content style="fixed-case">POV</jats:styled-content>) at 31% (<jats:italic>P</jats:italic> = 1.16 × 10−<jats:sup>47</jats:sup>) and 47% (<jats:italic>P</jats:italic> = 5.82 × 10−<jats:sup>20</jats:sup>), respectively. Rare/low frequency variants contributed more than common variants to variance in <jats:styled-content style="fixed-case">H</jats:styled-content>ispanics: <jats:styled-content style="fixed-case">POV</jats:styled-content> = 18% (<jats:italic>P</jats:italic> = 6.40 × 10−<jats:sup>15</jats:sup>) and <jats:styled-content style="fixed-case">POV</jats:styled-content> = 5% (<jats:italic>P</jats:italic> = 0.19), respectively. In <jats:styled-content style="fixed-case">A</jats:styled-content>frican <jats:styled-content style="fixed-case">A</jats:styled-content>mericans, rare/low frequency and common variants both contributed approximately equally to variance: <jats:styled-content style="fixed-case">POV</jats:styled-content> = 6% (<jats:italic>P</jats:italic> = 5.44 × 10−<jats:sup>12</jats:sup>) and <jats:styled-content style="fixed-case">POV</jats:styled-content> = 9% (<jats:italic>P</jats:italic> = 1.44 × 10−<jats:sup>10</jats:sup>), respectively. Importantly, single low frequency alleles in each ethnic group were as important as, or more important than, common variants in explaining variation in adiponectin. Cumulatively, these clinical and ethnicity‐specific genetic contributors explained half or more of the variance in <jats:styled-content style="fixed-case">H</jats:styled-content>ispanic and <jats:styled-content style="fixed-case">A</jats:styled-content>frican <jats:styled-content style="fixed-case">A</jats:styled-content>mericans and provide new insight into the sources of variation for this important adipocytokine.</jats:p>
